q: What are the symptoms of a febrile seizure?
a: During a febrile seizure, a child may become stiff, twitch, shake, or have jerking movements. They may also become unconscious, unresponsive, vomit, or wet themselves. After the seizure, they may be sleepy, irritable, or confused for up to 1 hour.

q: When should I call for immediate medical help during a febrile seizure?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if your child has a seizure for the first time, if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes, if they have difficulty breathing, if there is stiffness and twitching on only one side of their body, if they are excessively sleepy for more than 1 hour after the seizure stops, or if they have more than 1 seizure within 24 hours.

q: What should I do if my child is having a febrile seizure?
a: During a febrile seizure, you should protect your child's head, remove any nearby dangerous objects, and check the time the seizure starts and ends. After the seizure ends, put your child in the recovery position and ensure their mouth and throat are clear. Do not try to hold your child in place or put anything in their mouth.

q: Where can I learn how to put a baby in the recovery position?
a: You can find information on how to put a baby in the recovery position on the St John Ambulance website.

q: Is treatment necessary for febrile seizures?
a: Most febrile seizures do not require treatment. However, after the first febrile seizure, your child should be checked in the hospital. They may need tests such as blood and urine tests, and in some cases, a lumbar puncture. If an infection is causing the high temperature, treatment for the infection may be necessary.

q: What should I do if my child has recurrent febrile seizures?
a: In rare cases of recurrent febrile seizures, your doctor may prescribe medication to be given during a seizure. Your doctor will provide instructions on how to use the medication.

q: Can febrile seizures be prevented?
a: Febrile seizures cannot be prevented. They can occur when a child has an infection and a high temperature.

q: Are febrile seizures the same as epilepsy?
a: No, febrile seizures and epilepsy are not the same. Although there is a slightly increased chance of developing epilepsy after a febrile seizure, it is rare.

They may also become unconscious, not respond to you, be sick or wet themselves, and be sleepy, irritable, or confused for up to 1 hour afterwards. Febrile seizures usually last for 2 to 3 minutes and typically occur in children between 6 months and 6 years old.

a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if your child has a seizure for the first time, has a seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes, is having difficulty breathing, has stiffness and twitching on only one side of their body, is abnormally sleepy for more than 1 hour after the seizure stops, or has more than 1 seizure within 24 hours. Do not take your child to A&E if they are still having a seizure or are unconscious, call 999 instead.
